Controversy Explanation: The Cornell Political Union disinvited Stewart from a campus abortion debate, allegedly because of her traditional Christian views on marriage and sexuality. Organizers stressed that their decision had nothing to do with Stewart's views: Instead, they explained on their Facebook page: “As an undergraduate organization, we have limited funds, and paying for security would have put a great financial strain on the organization.”
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The VP of university relations told reporters: “They [the student club] made this decision without engaging with the administration on event planning or security. The University in no way requested or suggested that any guest be excluded from attending this campus event, and to date we have made no recommendation related to potential university costs associated with supporting the event. . . . As we have frequently noted, free speech is an essential part of Cornell University’s commitment to the discovery of truth, and the University’s leadership is resolute in upholding the principle of freedom of expression on our campuses."

Controversy Explanation: A student group canceled an annual performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, claiming it equates having a vagina with female identity and objecting to the play's author requiring that the monologues remain unchanged.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Kerrey withdrew as commencement speaker after the Nebraska Republican Party called on the university to disinvite Kerrey because of his support for abortion access. The university president said Kerry would speak at the Presidential Lecture Series later that year. Kerrey appeared at the lecture series and spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship). The president of the university said: "I appreciate his [Kerry's] desire not to have the focus of the day shifted away from our students." But he also said Kerry would be invited to lecture later.

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: During Livni's speech protestors began shouting the names of Palestinians that Israeli soldiers killed during the 2008-09 Gaza War and chanting, "You can’t hide, we charge you with genocide," at Livni for his role in Israeli policy regarding Palestine. Security escorted protestors out of the room and Livni finished his remarks.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Multiple student petitions called on the university to cancel Kingston's performance because of a past sexual assault allegation against Kingston. The dean of students canceled Kingston's performance.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Appeased Protesters. The Dean of Students said: "Now that these multiple perspectives have been heard, and we have had time to gather all available information—including additional concerns regarding Mr. Kingston’s appearance—I have decided to remove him from the Spring Weekend lineup. We are mindful that this is an extraordinary measure for the University to take, but also that the concerns raised are extraordinary and have been thoroughly discussed by the student organizations involved."

Controversy Explanation: Students, alumni, and university donors petitioned the university to disinvite Cupich from a campus religious conference over Cupich's views on abortion and homosexuality. Cupich spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The president of the university said:  "I, along with so many, have been profoundly disappointed by the troubling revelations about some of our bishops. . . . Yet, bishops receive their authority from Christ and unless that authority is officially taken away from them, I don't believe the Lord wants me to decide whether or not we should welcome this or that bishop."

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university, a private federally chartered university for the deaf and hard of hearing, to consider a deaf person for commencement speaker instead of Cole, who protesters said "has consistently voted against our values of diversity, inclusion, and equality." Cole spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled a performance by the rapper Fabolous because Fabolous was convicted of a domestic violence charge.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as Person, Appeased Protesters. The Director of Intercollegiate Athletics said: “After engaging with students, we have canceled the musical act for 2019 Hoya Madness. We take domestic violence very seriously and were unaware of the charges against the entertainer when he was booked through a third party entity.”

Controversy Explanation: Two separate petitions were circulated — one by outside organizations and one by students, alumni, and faculty — requesting that conference organizers rescind McAleenan’s invitation to speak because of his views on U.S. immigration policy. At the event, protestors repeatedly interrupted McAleenan, preventing him from starting his speech. Organizers tried to calm the crowd, but after making three failed attempts to begin his presentation, McAleenan thanked his hosts and left.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: After a hostile exchange between Crucet and a student during the Q&A portion of Crucet's talk on the topic of white privilege, students in attendance started shouting, yelling, and chanting. Later in the evening, after the event had concluded, students burned copies of Crucet's book on campus and some gathered outside her hotel, leading Crucet to change hotels.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A spokesperson said: “While it’s within the students’ First Amendment rights, book burning does not align with Georgia Southern’s values nor does it encourage the civil discourse and debate of ideas.”

Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. A statement from the Department of History said: "Book burning is at odds with our values of reasoned discourse, civil treatment of others, and openness towards ideas and experiences we might not share. Historically, book burning has been associated with intolerant and anti-democratic regimes. In the context of our diverse campus community, this symbolically potent action, combined with students’ online harassment of Professor Capó Crucet, who is Latina, reads as an act of intimidation. It represents a rejection of our core values, which include respect for others, reasoned intellectual inquiry, and an appreciation for our shared bonds. We condemn this behavior in the strongest of terms."

Controversy Explanation: Crucet was scheduled to make a second appearance at a different GSU campus the day after students burned her books in protest, claiming Crucert was guilty of “racism towards white people.” After the book burning protest the second event was canceled.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). Crucer posted on Twitter that the second appearance was canceled “because the administration said they could not guarantee my safety or the safety of its students on campus because of open carry laws.”

Controversy Explanation: Administrators required Martin to agree not to support a boycott of Israel as part of her honorarium contract, as required by Georgia law. When she refused, the university revoked the invitation. Martin filed a lawsuit and won.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The student government denied funding to Students for Life for a speaking event featuring King over King's "inherently religious" views on abortion and gay marriage. Students for Life filed a lawsuit over the denial of funds. The university settled and changed the policy that allowed the student government to deny funding based on a speaker's viewpoint.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The administration stated: “Georgia Tech holds freedom of expression as an essential cornerstone to the advancement of knowledge.

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled, but the university for the first time in its history allowed a public performance of the play.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled Shapiro's speech in order to “focus on opportunities that bring people together.” After receiving criticism of its decision, the university reinvited Shapiro to speak and he spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a person, Appeased Protesters. A university statement included: "Our decision to cancel Shapiro's speaking engagement is not a reflection of his ideologies or the values he represents, but rather a desire to focus on opportunities that bring people together."

Controversy Explanation: The Harvard Law School Forum, a student-run club, disinvited Fein because of Fein's views on the Armenian genocide, a topic on which he had not been asked to speak.
Public Response: None

School: Harvard University, The John F. Kennedy School of Government
Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Environment, Judiciary System
Controversy Explanation: Protesters occupied the stage and refused to leave during a speech by Long (and Lawrence S. Bacow). The protesters called for the university to divest from fossil fuels and prisons. The event was moved to another location and continued uninterrupted afterward.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. Dean of the Kennedy School told student protestors: “I understand that some of you want to make a point, and you can make that point, but I'm afraid [what] you can't do is to hinder the ability of other people here to listen to our speakers."

School: Harvard University, The John F. Kennedy School of Government
Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Environment, Judiciary System
Controversy Explanation: Protesters occupied the stage and refused to leave during a speech by Bacow (and Bridget Terry Long). The protesters called on the university to divest from fossil fuels and prisons. The event was moved to another location and continued uninterrupted afterward.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. Dean of the Kennedy School told student protestors: “I understand that some of you want to make a point, and you can make that point, but I'm afraid [what] you can't do is to hinder the ability of other people here to listen to our speakers."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The university canceled an annual student-organized drag show, claiming it might create "divisiveness" on campus.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university president issued a statement that included: “In my judgment, the drag show is not the best way to proceed. Rather, we need more and better programming that promotes the awareness and understanding of all identities on campus, especially our LGBTQIA+ students, and creates broader engagement.”

Controversy Explanation: University administrators pressured the College Democrats to disinvite Irvin from a student-run campus debate on abortion. Organizers reported that they were told by the administration that Irvin was too extreme and could potentially reflect badly on Loyola if outsiders were to believe Loyola had funded the event.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The Executive Director of Student Affairs told the school paper: “As we got nearer to the event, I did a little more research on the backgrounds of the various speakers and I was concerned that inviting a representative from the New Orleans Abortion Fund, which raises money to pay for legal abortions, ran counter to our Jesuit, Catholic values and the university’s official pro-life stance."

Controversy Explanation: A professor called on the university to cancel an event featuring Shapiro. Administrators initially required event organizers to answer "reflective questions" as a condition for approving the event but backed down after pushback. Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university released a statement that stated: "While the university engages in student developmental exercises designed to encourage thoughtful dialogue and assist with event planning, the process does not predetermined decisions nor diminish our support for speakers across a broad range of personal and political views."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite Watts from delivering a commencement speech because of Watts' support for the Defense of Marriage Act. Watts spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Health, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students, professors, and activist organizations petitioned the university to disinvite Swamy from the MIT India Conference because of Swamy's views on Muslims, homosexuality, and marginalized Indian communities. Swamy spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Topic(s): Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: The college canceled a speech by Legutko, citing safety concerns, following student protests over Legutko's conservative political views. A Middlebury College professor invited Legutko to speak in his class instead.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). College administrators released a statement that stated: “It [the event Cancellation] was based on an assessment of our ability to respond effectively to potential security and safety risks for both the lecture and the event students had planned in response.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to disinvite Shriver from delivering a commencement speech because of Shriver's pro-choice views and his advocacy for sex-education and family planning. Students and alumni also petitioned the university to rescind Shriver's invitation, accruing more than 22,000 signatures. Shriver spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president said: "To invite someone to speak at any event on campus is not an endorsement of every statement or action of that speaker. Instead, the invitation expresses our confidence in that person's ability to inspire or educate our students, in order to deepen their understanding of how they can live lives of significance in service to God and others."

Controversy Explanation: Radical Alert started a petition to disinvite Sarsour from participating in a campus event, objecting to Sarsour's views on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Sarsour spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A university spokesperson said that “it is the policy of the University to permit open dialogue and to support academic freedom."

Source(s): Alumni, Anonymous, Faculty, Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Students, faculty, staff, and alumni petitioned the university to disinvite Spicer from a talk because of his role in the Trump administration. Spicer spoke successfully but during his presentation a protester rushed the stage and was arrested.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. A university spokesperson said that there were “a couple of minor disruptions . . . [but overall the event] did what it intended to do which was give debate to important topics of the day. . . . And we were able to have peaceful protests on campus, so people who choose to protest made their voices heard inside the auditorium and were heard by media coverage of the event. . . . We absolutely respect their right to do that.”

Controversy Topic(s): Political Views, Race, Class or Policy Issues, immigration
Controversy Explanation: Student protesters disrupted a speaking event featuring Sessions hosted by the College Republicans. Protesters climbed in windows and pushed past security, shouting about Sessions' immigration policies and calling him racist. Police eventually secured the event hall and Sessions finished his talk despite the disruptions.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Students called on the university to cancel Kingston's performance because a sexual assault allegation made against the singer in 2010. The student newspaper protested the administration's decision to allow Kingston to perform by publishing an editorial that urged the university to "follow the lead of those other universities that have taken a stand and make it clear that they truly stand with survivors" and refusing to cover the event. Kingston performed successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Political Views, Race
Controversy Explanation: Police stood idly by while a student activist used a cowbell to disrupt a speaking event featuring Strickland. The student was acting in revenge for Strickland having pointed a gun at him two years ago during a BLM protest. The charges against Strickland are still in litigation and Strickland claims he pointed the gun in self-defense since he was surrounded by BLM protesters, some with sticks. It took about an hour for the bell-ringing student to leave, but once he did, Strickland's talk proceeded as planned.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university statement read: “When an individual disrupted the event by ringing a cowbell, the officer used his professional judgment and determined not to threaten or restrain the individual so as not to escalate a potentially unsafe situation.”

Controversy Explanation: The American Whig-Cliosophic Society (Whig-Clio), who had rescinded Wax's invitation to speak on-campus a year earlier, reinvited Wax (and Keith Whittington) to appear at a campus free speech event. The student newspaper editorial board called on Whig-Clio to disinvite Wax from a campus talk due to Wax's views on immigration, race, and American culture. The club disavowed its support of Wax and said the decision to invite her was made by trustees of the society and against student recommendation. Wax (and Whittington) spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The American Whig-Cliosophic Society, which canceled an event featuring Whittington and Amy Wax a year prior because of Wax's views on immigration, race, and American culture, reinvited Whittington (and Wax) to appear at a campus free speech event. The student newspaper editorial board called on Whig-Clio to disinvite Wax again. The club disavowed its support of Wax and said the decision to invite her was made by trustees of the society and against student recommendation. Whittington (and Wax) spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Topic(s): Foreign Affairs, Gender, Political Views, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite Pence from a campus talk about Venezuela, objecting to Pence's views on LGBT issues and his conservative beliefs. Pence spoke successfully while protests occurred on campus.
Public Response: None

Source(s): Activist(s), General Public, Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Community members, student groups, students, and activists petitioned — receiving almost 20,000 signatures — and protested Martin’s speaking appearance at an LGBT group's on-campus event, claiming Martin's views on homosexuality and transgenderism went against Catholic doctrine. The university president derided protesters, saying their protests were an attempt at "bullying" and “laden with bigotry and self-righteousness.” Martin spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The president posted that he had received “an outpouring of letters, emails and calls regarding Martin’s views . . . laden with bigotry and self-righteousness. . . .[attempts at] bullying” . . . [and contrary to] open debate and discourse. [But he was not going to be swayed]"

Source(s): Activist(s), General Public, Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Students, student groups, activists, and the general public signed a petition to stop Martin from speaking at the university because of Martin's views on sexual orientation. The petition garnered almost 20,000 signatures but the university administration refused to disinvite Martin and he spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: A faculty committee canceled Fish's speech in the wake of student protests demanding that the university English department focus more on racial issues.
Public Response: None

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Police, Race
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the college to rescind its invitation of Bottoms to speak at commencement because of Bottoms' support for policies "catalyzing the gentrification of West End Atlanta" and because of how Bottoms responded to the homelessness crisis and the deaths of two black men shot and killed by Atlanta police officers. Bottoms spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The university president said in announcing the speaker event "Atlanta is fortunate to have such a dynamic leader as Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms, who has had a tremendous impact on the city, in particular on the Westside, where Spelman is located."

Source(s): Activist(s), General Public, Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: A fraternity disinvited Lonsdale from an event on public policy, technology, and entrepreneurship after a university student he had mentored made sexual assault, gender violence, and sexual harassment allegations against him. While there are inconsistencies in how the Title IX investigation results are reported, it seems the findings for some of the worst of the allegations were reversed. However, Lonsdale was sanctioned for not disclosing his relationship with an undergraduate he was mentoring, as required by university policy.
Public Response: None

School: State University of New York, Oneonta
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to cancel Kingston's performance and planned to protest if Kingston performed, citing a past sexual assault allegation against Kingston. The city pulled the permit allowing the event to take place in the park because it felt the university lacked an adequate plan for dealing with anticipated protests. Once the permit was revoked, the university claimed 36 hours wasn't enough time to arrange for a different location and the performance was canceled.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The vice president of student development said: "We regret needing to make this choice and acknowledge it will disappoint members of Oneonta’s campus communities and many others. However, the college, no matter the circumstances, must act in students’ best interests."

Controversy Explanation: Students, faculty, and alumni petitioned the university to disinvite then-Vice President Pence from delivering a commencement speech, claiming Pence's political views do not align with Christian values. Others petitioned in favor of allowing Pence to speak. A number of students and faculty walked out of the commencement ceremony during Pence's speech, but the speech proceeded without disruption.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university published a statement that included: “Taylor University is honored to have Vice President Mike Pence featured as our commencement speaker. Mr. Pence has been a good friend to the University over many years, and is a Christian brother whose life and values have exemplified what we strive to instill in our graduates.”

School: The Savannah College of Art and Design, The University for Creative Careers
Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Gender, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the college to rescind its invitation of Morino to speak at commencement because of several sexual assault, harassment, and slander charges against Morino. Morino spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

School: The United States Army War College
Controversy Explanation: The college disinvited Ibrahim after receiving criticism, including letters and a petition started by outside groups, of Ibrahim's views on Islam and Muslim-West relations. The National Association of Scholars organized a counter-petition/open letter to send to then-President Trump to ask him to intervene on Ibrahim's behalf.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. A college spokesperson issued a statement that included: "The presentation of Mr. Raymond Ibrahim’s book is postponed so USAHEC can pair Mr. Ibrahim’s military history insights in close proximity with another historical perspective, at a time when the USAWC curriculum has addressed historical analysis of influences on conflict.”

Controversy Explanation: The student government unanimously voted against funding Mac Donald's talk on campus, objecting to the amount of funding requested and describing the speaker's viewpoints on university diversity and inclusion offices as controversial. The student government seemed to have been influenced by the university president and dean of students, who attended a meeting and expressed their disapproval of Mac Donald.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Students protested Coulter's speech on immigration. Police escorted attendees into the event because protesters began pushing them and chanting, "Don't let them in." Six or more protesters were arrested outside the venue and one was arrested inside. Despite some heckling, Coulter finished her talk.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A university spokesperson told reporters: “We have work to continue to find ways we can accommodate profound differences of opinion. We believe we have met our obligations to both free speech and the rule of law, and to provide for the safety and well-being of students and campus guests."

Controversy Explanation: Turning Point USA hosted an event featuring Trump Jr. (and Kimberly Guilfoyle). During the event, supporters of Trump Jr.'s father, former President Trump, heckled Trump Jr. and disrupted the event after learning that Turning Point USA had canceled the Q&A session.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Turning Point USA hosted an event featuring Guilfoyle (and Donald Trump Jr.). During the event, supporters of Trump Jr.'s father, former President Trump, heckled Trump Jr. and disrupted the event after learning the Q&A session had been canceled by Turning Point USA.
Public Response: None
